EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
 Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding Pilot of Early Alert Program 
	 
The African-American Student Advocates will provide an update regarding the efforts to implement a process for alerting parents when a student is not performing well in classes.
	 
Each of the high schools have committed to continue to promote the use of Schoolloop by teachers, students, and parents as a means to monitor student progress.
Schools will offer Schoolloop training to teachers at the beginning of the school year in order to increase teacher participation.
Schools will offer Schoolloop training to parents and assist them in registering in Schoolloop.
The district is currently pursuing ways that an automatic notification can be sent to parents notifying them that their child is in danger of failing.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  11.03
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Bob Bush, SGI Bond Project Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation an Update on Measure E Unfunded Projects Analysis 
		 
		 
At its public meeting of December 8, 2011, the Board of Trustees for the East Side Union High School District considered the Measure E Forecast & Spending Plan and attendant recommendations from staff.  Given anticipated limitations on available Measure E Bond funding, the Board approved moving forward with Phases I & II of Measure E, as planned, and a limited Phase III focused on closing equity distribution gaps. This approach considered deferment of $79 Million in scope for the Measure E Bond Program.
		 
At its public meeting of March 8, 2012, the Board was informed of options for disposition of the remaining $79 Million in voter approved authorization by Bond Advisor, Dale Scott & Company. It is in this context that the Board requested staff to compile a list of projects that would not be completed if no further funding were made available under Measure E.
		 
In 2007 - 2008 a priority list of projects, reflective of total need at that time, was systematically developed by staff, sites, and cabinet. This list was considered and approved in counterpart by the Board of Trustees, starting in February, 2009 and concluding in October, 2009.  Completion of the entire list was subject to availability of funds. After the completion of Phases I, II, and a limited Phase III of the Measure E Program, approximately $190 Million in projects identified on the priority list would remain unfunded. This list of unfunded projects was reviewed by the Board at the public meeting of April 19, 2012.
		 
Alternative scenarios are available, subject to the Board’s discretion, to move forward to address scope needs ranging from $79 - $190 Million, based on the list of “Unfunded Projects”.  Inasmuch as specific projects, as previously enumerated, were defined as early as 2007, many of these projects must be revalidated through a process involving school sites, administration, and the Board before subsequent planning and construction can take place. This revalidation process will commence upon the action of the Board to proceed with plans to further fund the Capital Construction Program at East Side.
		 
During the meeting of April 19, 2012, the Board also began to examine options that would help to ensure continuity of the District’s capital construction program. Staff was directed to provide further information on both the potential projects as well as options for funding these projects. Accordingly, staff has prepared a review of projects, attached. Options for funding will be the subject of a separate presentation, which follows.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  11.04
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Dale Scott, Dale Scott and Company, and Charles Adams, Jones Hall
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Adoption of Resolution #2011/2012-39A or #2011/2012-39B Ordering an Election to Authorize the Issuance of School Bonds, Establishing Specifications of the Election Order, and Requesting Consolidation with Other Elections Occurring on November 6, 2012  
		 
		 
District staff calculates its capital project funding needs over the next 10 years to be approximately $200 million. The Board has been presented with two funding alternatives to address these needs.  Alternative A would seek voter approval to reauthorize $78 million of the 2008 Measure E GO bonds. These bonds cannot be sold today at a reasonable cost due to Proposition 39 tax rate limitations.  An additional ballot measure would be needed in 2016 to generate the remaining required funding. Alternative B would place a $120 million new money GO bond on the November 2012 ballot.  After these funds are expended, the remaining Measure E bonds would be issued once assessed valuations have risen.  Agenda item 11.04 provides alternative resolutions for these two options. An analysis by the District’s financial advisor has calculated the difference in the cost to taxpayers between these two alternatives to be negligible.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
		 
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To be determined
		 
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the passage of the Alternative B resolution calling for a $120 new bond measure to be placed on the November 2012 ballot.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion/Action to Approve App Development and Cooperation Agreement
	 
	 
A current District student (minor age) has developed a unique mobile phone app that integrates all of his school site’s website and student functions (e.g., SchoolLoop, site map, etc.) from a single button.  The app is interesting and potentially useful to students and parents throughout the District.  Student, with the consent of his parents, would like to make the app accessible and functional at all of the District’s school sites and at no cost to the District.  The proposed agreement (between District and student’s parents on behalf of the minor student) will allow student to begin work on the app for the other school sites without any cost to the District.  In creating and programming, the app student will not be granted access to confidential information under any circumstance.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration and Legal Counsel recommend that the Board approve the proposed agreement as presented.

SUBJECT:
Appointment of Board Secretary
	 
	 
	 
With the pending retirement of Superintendent Moser, pursuant to BB 9122, the Governing Board shall appoint the new Superintendent to serve as Secretary to the Board, effective July 1, 2012.  The Secretary to the Board shall be responsible for maintaining an accurate and complete record of all Board proceedings and duties as outlined under Board Bylaws 9122.
	 
	 
	 
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board appoint Chris Funk as Board Secretary, effective July 1, 2012.

SUBJECT:
Approve 2012 Single Plan for Student Achievement
	 
The purpose of the Single Plan for Student Achievement (SPSA) is to create a cycle of continuous improvement of student performance, and to ensure that all students succeed in reaching academic standards set by the State Board of Education.
	 
The District Advisory Council (DAC) and the District English Learners Advisory Council (DELAC) have reviewed the school goals, budget, and plans.  The abstracts for the school plan are included in this packet while complete copies of the plans are available for Trustee review in the Instructional Services Division, as requested.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the 2012 Single Plan for Student Achievement as indicated herein, and that the Superintendent is authorized to make modifications as needed.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services and Rich Uribe, Director of Adult Education and Career Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve Carl D. Perkins 131 Grant 2012-13 Grant Application for East Side Union High School District
		 
		 
Overview:
The East Side Career Technical Education Program includes the AH Multimedia Academy, AH Culinary Arts Pathway, AH Biotechnology Academy, AH Health/Nursing Academy, AH Public Services Academy, IH Automotive, MP Manufacturing Academy, MP Animation Pathway, WCO Early Childhood Education Academy, WCO Multimedia Academy, WCO Electronics Academy, PH CAD Pathway, PH Entrepreneurship Pathway, PH Carpentry Pathway, OG Travel and Tourism Academy, OG International Cuisine Pathway, SC Business Careers Pathway, YB Construction Academy, YB Pre-Engineering Pathway, IH Academy of Finance, IH Engineering Space Science Pathway, IH Carpentry, IH Teaching Academy, and the ST Multimedia Pathway.
		 
Program Support:
Perkins funds will be used to assist programs in the Arts, Media and Entertainment Industry Sector, the Building Trades and Construction Industry Sector, Education, Child Development and Family Services Industry, Energy and Utilities Industry Sector, Engineering and Design Industry Sector, Finance and Business Industry Sector, Health, Science and Medical Technology Industry Sector, Hospitality, Tourism and Recreation Industry Sector, Transportation Industry Sector and the Public Services Industry Sector.  Funds will also be used  to support Certificated FTE for courses that will be offered for the first time at Andrew Hill, James Lick and WC Overfelt High Schools.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006, Section 131
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D. Perkins 131 Grant 2012-13 Grant Application for the East Side Union High School District.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  14.01
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Adoption of 2012-2013 Budget 
		 
		 
Per Education Code Section 42103, the East Side Union High School District held a Public Hearing on June 7, 2012, on the Preliminary Budget for 2012/2013.  The annual budget for 2012/2013 is being presented for adoption. 
		 
The 2012-13 Adopted budget reflects the actions and input of the Governing Board, Superintendent, stakeholders, and staff to develop a budget that is responsive to district needs and priorities.  The final budget was prepared taking into account all changes relative to the Governor’s May revision proposal.  This budget year has proved to be especially challenging given the dire economic and fiscal circumstances within the State.  In addition, information regarding the States fiscal status seems to change on a constant basis.  In spite of all the challenges, the district has managed to maintain current programs and services. 
		 
The 2012-13 budget indicates that the district is recommending that a positive budget be adopted based on the district’s ability to maintain sufficient reserves for the upcoming and two subsequent fiscal years.  In addition, the district would be able to meet its obligations in the upcoming and two subsequent fiscal years.  Currently, the district does not project any reductions in fiscal year 2012-13 and will continue to monitor the State budget situation and the pending November ballot initiative.  If the Governor’s recommended tax measure is not approved by the voters, the Governor has promised a take-back of $441 per average daily attendance. For ESUHSD, the take-back would represent an estimated $10 million per year.  The district would have sufficient reserves in FY 2012-13 in the event of a take-back, however, the district’s remaining reserves would be depleted by FY 2014-15.  The district has prepared a contingency plan which would require reductions of $6.6 million in FY 2012-13, $16.6 million in FY 13-14, and $16.7 million in FY 14-15. This scenario would be catastrophic for ESUHSD and all K-12 education.  We will continue to monitor and report on the State’s budget circumstances and how it impacts the district as information becomes available.         
		 
The attached budget book with executive summary provides a more detailed analysis of the FY 2012-13 district budget and required State SACS reporting forms.  
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and adopt the annual budget for 2012/2013.
